articles.headline: For Obama, Housing Policy Presents Second-Term Headaches
articles.snippet: President Obama’s economic team has consistently said it wants the housing market to work without significant government support. But it has taken few actual steps to advance that idea.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s economic team has consistently said it wants the housing market to work without significant government support. But it has taken few actual steps to advance that idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: A second-term president may be just the person to tackle America’s housing problems.

articles.headline: Iran Fired on Military Drone in First Such Attack, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Pentagon officials said that while a surveillance drone targeted in international airspace over the Persian Gulf last week was not hit, the incident prompted a strong protest to Tehran.
articles.abstract: Pentagon officials said that while a surveillance drone targeted in international airspace over the Persian Gulf last week was not hit, the incident prompted a strong protest to Tehran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iranian warplanes shot at an American military surveillance drone flying over the Persian Gulf near Iran last week, Pentagon officials disclosed Thursday. They said that the aircraft, a Predator drone, was flying in international airspace and was not hit and that the episode had prompted a strong protest to the Iranian government.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: A Casino Strategy, Rated AAA
articles.snippet: A judge in Australia found that Standard & Poor’s was liable for issuing the top rating of AAA for a product she described as a “grotesquely complicated” piece of financial engineering.
articles.abstract: A judge in Australia found that Standard & Poor’s was liable for issuing the top rating of AAA for a product she described as a “grotesquely complicated” piece of financial engineering.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Laws, like sausages, cease to inspire respect in proportion as we know how they are made.”

articles.headline: Popular Wrench Fights a Chinese Rival
articles.snippet: Sears, which sold many Bionic Wrenches last holiday season, is selling a similar product this year — only now it is made in China instead of America.
articles.abstract: Sears, which sold many Bionic Wrenches last holiday season, is selling a similar product this year — only now it is made in China instead of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Christmas, Sears had a brisk seller in the Bionic Wrench, an award-winning, patented tool with spiffy lime green accents. This holiday season, though, Sears has a special display for its own wrench, in the red and black colors of its house brand, Craftsman.

articles.headline: For Romney, All His Career Options Are Still Open. Except One.
articles.snippet: After a failed presidential bid and three decades of remarkably seamless career hopping, Mitt Romney is now a restless chief executive with no organization to run.
articles.abstract: After a failed presidential bid and three decades of remarkably seamless career hopping, Mitt Romney is now a restless chief executive with no organization to run.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — They predict he will write a book, convinced that the daily diary he kept on the campaign trail would make for a compelling read.

articles.headline: Tied by Heartstrings to Calamity
articles.snippet: Americans who live overseas, worried about family and the old neighborhood, figured out how to help after Hurricane Sandy.
articles.abstract: Americans who live overseas, worried about family and the old neighborhood, figured out how to help after Hurricane Sandy.
articles.lead_paragraph: USUALLY, Liz Cohen’s mother on Staten Island is the one making urgent, middle-of-the-night phone calls to check on her daughter’s safety in Israel. But when Hurricane Sandy swamped Ms. Cohen’s former neighborhood last month, she frantically dialed her mother, Janet MeresmanCohen, in New York.

articles.headline: Getting Back More Than a Warm Feeling
articles.snippet: Some investors and nonprofits are finding mutual interest through “social impact bonds,” which support social programs with an eye toward a profit.
articles.abstract: Some investors and nonprofits are finding mutual interest through “social impact bonds,” which support social programs with an eye toward a profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE seven teenagers sit with their feet tucked under tan desks in a classroom in New York City’s Rikers Island jail, taking turns answering “icebreaker” questions they’ve fished from an envelope.

articles.headline: In Veterans’ Aid, Growth Pains
articles.snippet: Since 2001, more than 7,800 nonprofit groups have registered with the federal government to care for troops, veterans and their families.
articles.abstract: Since 2001, more than 7,800 nonprofit groups have registered with the federal government to care for troops, veterans and their families.
articles.lead_paragraph: GATHERING over a kitchen table and glasses of wine in early 2003, a group of officers’ wives at Camp Pendleton, Calif., cobbled together a plan for helping Marines injured during the invasion of Iraq.

articles.headline: Missteps by Rebels Erode Their Support Among Syrians
articles.snippet: The Syrian public is increasingly disgusted with the actions of some rebels, including poorly planned missions, senseless destruction, criminal behavior and the coldblooded killing of prisoners.
articles.abstract: The Syrian public is increasingly disgusted with the actions of some rebels, including poorly planned missions, senseless destruction, criminal behavior and the coldblooded killing of prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s rebel fighters — who have long staked claim to the moral high ground for battling dictatorship — are losing crucial support from a public increasingly disgusted by the actions of some rebels, including poorly planned missions, senseless destruction, criminal behavior and the coldblooded killing of prisoners.

articles.headline: In Michigan, a Setback for Unions
articles.snippet: Perhaps fearing that they would be giving too much power to unions, voters defeated a Constitutional amendment that would have guaranteed the right to collective bargaining.
articles.abstract: Perhaps fearing that they would be giving too much power to unions, voters defeated a Constitutional amendment that would have guaranteed the right to collective bargaining.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoping to set a precedent for other states, Michigan’s labor unions spent months pushing a referendum to amend the state’s Constitution to prohibit the legislature from ever enacting a law that would curb the powers of public employee unions.

articles.headline: Congress Sees Rising Urgency on Fiscal Deal
articles.snippet: Lawmakers said Thursday that they were trying to strike a deal that would avert a fiscal crisis next year when trillions of dollars in tax increases and automatic spending cuts begin to go into force.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers said Thursday that they were trying to strike a deal that would avert a fiscal crisis next year when trillions of dollars in tax increases and automatic spending cuts begin to go into force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior lawmakers said Thursday that they were moving quickly to take advantage of the postelection political atmosphere to try to strike an agreement that would avert a fiscal crisis early next year when trillions of dollars in tax increases and automatic spending cuts begin to go into force.

articles.headline: Debt Ceiling Complicates a Tax Shift
articles.snippet: Congressional leaders have made clear that the debt ceiling will be part of talks over the so-called fiscal cliff, with many members unwilling to raise the ceiling without a broader deal.
articles.abstract: Congressional leaders have made clear that the debt ceiling will be part of talks over the so-called fiscal cliff, with many members unwilling to raise the ceiling without a broader deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Come January, should Congress fail to act, the United States will face more than immense tax increases and spending cuts. It will also run out of room to finance its large running deficits.
